metadata.description: Zambian Tonga (ChiTonga) as spoken in Southern Province

examples: Mwabuka - Good morning
Mwabuka buti - How is your morning
Mwabuka buti bonse - Good morning everyone
Mwabonwa - Hello (in response)
Mwabonwa kapati - Warm greetings
Twalumba kapati - Thank you very much
Twalumba kukutola - Thank you for giving me a lift
Twalumba kucita mulimo - Thank you for the work
Mwabuka buti - Good morning
Mwabuka buti bonse - Good morning everyone
Ku nyina mali iwi - You have no money
Waamba kuti ku nyina mali iwi - He's saying you have no money
ku nyina mali iwi.culturalContext: Direct statement about financial status, commonly used in economic transactions
ku nyina mali iwi.usage: Used to indicate someone is broke or has insufficient funds

examples: Imita ufole - Get pregnant and get paid
Bamakaintu baamba kuti imita ufole - Women say get pregnant and get paid
imita ufole.culturalContext: Expression that refers to situations where pregnancy leads to financial compensation or support
imita ufole.usage: Social commentary phrase, sometimes used in discussions about relationships and responsibility

examples: Inganda yangu - My house
Ndaya ku inganda - I am going to the house
inganda.culturalContext: The home is a central part of Tonga family and social life
inganda.usage: Used to refer to a person's home or a dwelling

examples: Ndaya ku chintolo - I am going to the shop
Chintolo nchigali - The shop is closed
chintolo.culturalContext: Shops are important for commerce and social interaction in Tonga communities
chintolo.usage: Refers to a place where goods are sold

examples: Ndaya ku musika - I am going to the market
Musika uli a bantu - The market is full of people
musika.culturalContext: Markets are central to the economic and social life of Tonga communities
musika.usage: Refers to a marketplace or bazaar

examples: Ndaya ku chikombelo - I am going to church
Chikombelo chaanza - Church has started
chikombelo.culturalContext: Christianity and churches play a significant role in many Tonga communities
chikombelo.usage: Refers to a place of Christian worship

examples: Ndaya ku chibadela - I am going to the hospital
Ula ku chibadela - He/she is at the hospital
chibadela.culturalContext: Hospitals are critical for healthcare in Tonga regions
chibadela.usage: Refers to a medical facility for treatment

examples: Ndaya ku cikolo - I am going to school
Cikolo chijedwe - The school is closed
cikolo.culturalContext: Education and schools are highly valued in Tonga society

examples: Twajaya nyama ku syokwe - We killed an animal in the jungle
Syokwe nchitali - The jungle is big
syokwe.culturalContext: Forests or bush areas, important for resources and traditional practices
syokwe.usage: Refers to a forest, bush, or wilderness area

examples: Mulonga uli a meenda - The river has water
Twalozya mulonga - We crossed the river
mulonga.culturalContext: Rivers are vital sources of water and livelihood in Tonga lands
mulonga.usage: Refers to a river or large stream

examples: Nzila mbotu - The road is good
Tulatobela nzila - We are following the road
nzila.culturalContext: Roads connect villages and are essential for transport and communication
nzila.usage: Refers to a road, path, or way
